of Molecular Catalysis, 75 (1992) 101-107 101 M2941 1,3-Dioxolane formation with a montmorillonite-type clay catalyst A. Cabrera, D. Vazquez, L. Velasco, M. Salmon* Instituto de Quimica UNAM, Circuito Exterior, Ciudad Universitaria, Coyoacdn 04510 D. F. (Mexico) and J. L. Arias Facultad O Estudios Superiores Cuautitldn UNAM, Cuautitlkn Izcalli, Estado de Mdxico (Mexico) (Received October 7, 1991; revised March 1, 1922) Abstract The coupling reaction of oxiranes with carbonyl compounds to produce 1,3-dioxolanes was promoted by catalytic amounts of a bentonitic clay. The product yield was found to be dependent on the catalyst, the reaction temperature and the reagent concentrations. A kinetic study performed with acetone and ethylene oxide showed a first-order dependence in both reagents. Other experiments made with different epoxides, carbonyl compounds and catalysts are also discussed. Introduction The Bronsted and Lewis properties of some clay minerals have been used in the transformation of organic compounds [ 1 ], particularly in reactions involving alkene oxides yielding ethers [1, 2], esters [3], aldehydes [4] and dioxolanes [5]. This last process is also important because of its protective carbonyl group application. In this study we report the use of a Mexican montmorillonite clay to form 1,3-dioxolanes directly and selectively from a coupling reaction between epoxides and ketones or aldehydes. It should also be mentioned that this particular clay has a dual catalytic effect, inducing free radicals and catalytic electrophilic substitutions within the same system [6]. Experimental On examination by X-ray fluorescence, the clay employed in this study proved to have the following composition (in aNu): Si02, 75.4; A1203, 9.3; *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved 102 MgO, 0.4; Fe203, 1.3; CaO, 4.0; K20, 0.4; Ti02; 0.4; H20 (110 ) 9.5. The commercial acid-activated material was obtained from Tonsil Mexicana and analyzed with a Phillips spectrometer using Cr primary radiation. The measured specific surface area was 307 m2/g (B.E.T. N2) and the pore volume was 0.4789 cm/g. The acidity by NH3 thermodesorption was 0.099 meq/g. The particle size was 325 mesh. Other inorganic materials studied as comparative catalysts were silica gel (Merck), alumina F-20 (Alcoa), SnC12 (Aldrich) and HCl (Baker). The organic reagents were: ethylene oxide (Matheson), propylene and phenylethylene oxides (Aldrich); epibromohydrin, epichlorohydrin and acetone were supplied by (Merck), 2-pentanone, 4-methyl-2-pentanone, butyraldehyde and valeraldehyde were purchased from Aldrich. The dioxolane formation was carried out in a sealed glass reactor containing 0.25 g of clay, previously dried at 250 C, in the selected ketone or aldehyde, and the corresponding epoxide in a molar ratio of 2:1. The reaction mixture was heated to 70 C and stirred for 3 h; the catalyst was then separated by centrifugation and the organic solution analyzed by GC in a Hewlett Packard 5890 chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and a 20 m X 0.2 mm glass column packed with Carbowax 20M. Purified samples were analyzed on a FT80 'H NMR spectrometer using CDC13 and TMS as internal reference. The GC-mass spectrometric analyses were performed using a Hewlett Packard 5895 GC/MS spectrometer equipped with a flame ionization detector and a 25 m X 0.3 mm column packed with 5% phenyl methyl silicone. A Polyscience Corporation model 73 temperature controller was employed for the kinetic measurements. Effect of pyridine concentration on the formation of 1,3-dioxolane. Temperature 70 C; ethylene oxide 0.1 mol; acetone 0.2 mol; reaction time 5 h; clay 0.25 g. obtained when the epoxide or carbonyl concentration is maintained constant, as is shown in Tables 1 and 2. In both cases the formation process is inhibited by increasing carbonyl chain length or by epoxide substitution, which implies strong steric effects. 1n 5 h reaction, no critical concentration of catalyst was required to induce the dioxolane formation, whereas the activity increased with catalyst concentration, as shown in Wig. 1. However, the coupling reaction can be inhibited by adding pyridine, suggesting the aromatic amine coordinates with the A13+ centers thus lowering the acidity [4]. FSgure 2 shows the plot of the rate of 1,3-oxirane production vs. the amount of pyridine added to the bentonite clay. It should be noted that 0.005 mmol amine per gram of solid will reduce the 1,3-dioxolane formation by 80ss'o. In order to study the effect of substrate and reagent concentrations on the process, a series of experiments was performed with acetone and ethylene oxide at 70 C using 0.25 g of bentonite. figure 3 shows the plot of the dioxolane yield vs. time, varying the amount of acetone and maintaining the oxirane concentration constant in order to determine the initial rate (Vo). Reactions performed without catalyst yielded negative results. Other catalysts were also studied to compare the catalytic activity of the surface studied in this work. The results, given in Table 3, show that only the bentonite clay yielded the dioxolane derivative in a quantitative amount. 107 Acknowledgements MS gratefully acknowledges the partial financial support of this project by DGAPA-UNAM IN301791.
